questions.question: Three hours post-thyroidectomy, a 30-year-old woman developed agitation, difficulty breathing, tachycardia, and a dry dressing, but anterior cervical swelling. The most appropriate immediate step is:
questions.explanation: Immediate post-op respiratory distress, agitation, and neck swelling suggest a tension hematoma; the wound must be urgently reopened to relieve tracheal compression.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 17-year-old girl presented with a 2.5 cm nodule in the right lobe of the thyroid gland and enlarged cervical lymph nodes confirmed by ultrasound. FNA cytology revealed malignant cells with vesicular nuclei. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy, often affecting young females. It spreads via lymphatics to cervical nodes and is characterized cytologically by vesicular nuclei.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 30-year-old female presents for evaluation of a palpable thyroid nodule. A Tc99 scan demonstrated a single cold nodule. This may be any of the following except:
questions.explanation: A 'cold' nodule on a scan indicates hypofunctioning tissue. An autonomous nodule functions independently of TSH and is hyperfunctioning, appearing 'hot' or 'warm' on a scan, not cold.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A familial form of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) should be suspected whenever:
options: The tumor is bilateral (foci of tumor are present in both thyroid lobes)
Pathologic examination of the resected thyroid gland reveals C-cell hyperplasia adjacent to MTC
questions.explanation: Familial MTC (associated with MEN syndromes) is typically bilateral, multifocal, and associated with background C-cell hyperplasia, unlike sporadic cases which are usually unilateral and solitary.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A middle-aged woman with a history of childhood irradiation has a solid, cold thyroid nodule. What is the appropriate next step?
questions.explanation: Childhood irradiation raises malignancy risk in a solid, cold thyroid nodule; high suspicion warrants diagnostic and therapeutic lobectomy rather than just FNAC.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A thyroid nodule may be malignant if it shows:
questions.explanation: Malignancy features include hardness (infiltration), rapid growth (anaplastic/lymphoma), referred pain (nerve involvement), and hoarseness (recurrent laryngeal nerve invasion).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All are causes of hypercalcemia, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid arises from parafollicular C-cells, which secrete calcitonin. Calcitonin tends to lower blood calcium, not cause hypercalcemia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following are recognized complications of Neomercazole (Carbimazole) except:
questions.explanation: Neomercazole can cause agranulocytosis, hepatotoxicity, and iatrogenic goiter. It is not typically associated with renal failure.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding retrosternal goiter, which statement is false?
options: It usually arises in aberrant intrathoracic thyroid tissue
It is particularly common in males
It may present with symptoms of mediastinal compression
It is often associated with palpable enlargement of the thyroid
It is best removed through a cervical incision
questions.explanation: Retrosternal goiters typically arise from the lower pole of a cervical thyroid gland that grows downwards into the chest, not from separate aberrant intrathoracic tissue.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding the embryology of the thyroid:
questions.explanation: The thyroid gland develops from an endodermal diverticulum arising from the midline floor of the primitive pharynx at the foramen cecum. It is not derived from any branchial (pharyngeal) arch. Branchial arches form skeletal and muscular structures (e.g., the 4th arch forms thyroid cartilage), while the thyroid gland itself originates from endoderm. Parafollicular C-cells are derived from the ultimobranchial body of the 4th pharyngeal pouch, not from the 4th branchial arch.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding T3:
options: It has a lower concentration than circulating T4
It is more potent than T4
It is mostly bound to TBG
questions.explanation: T3 is produced in smaller quantities than T4 but is significantly more biologically active. Like T4, it is largely bound to Thyroid Binding Globulin (TBG) in the blood.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding FNABC, all statements are correct EXCEPT:
options: It cannot differentiate follicular adenoma from carcinoma
questions.explanation: Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNABC) is a simple outpatient procedure performed under local or no anesthesia; it does not require general anesthesia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Autoimmune manifestations of Graves' disease include the following except:
questions.explanation: Exophthalmos, Pretibial Myxedema, and Thyroid Acropachy are specific autoimmune features of Graves'. Palmar erythema is a non-specific sign of thyrotoxicosis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: C-cells of the thyroid gland:
options: Are the origin of medullary carcinoma
questions.explanation: C-cells (parafollicular cells) originate from the neural crest (ultimobranchial body), secrete calcitonin, and their malignancy leads to Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Clinical pictures of thyroid carcinoma include:
questions.explanation: Thyroid carcinoma may cause pressure symptoms (dyspnea, dysphagia), nerve invasion (hoarseness, ear pain), carotid encasement (Berry’s sign), and lymph node metastasis (lateral aberrant thyroid).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Excision of a thyroglossal cyst should include removal of:
questions.explanation: The Sistrunk procedure for thyroglossal cysts requires removing the cyst, the tract, and the central body of the hyoid bone to prevent recurrence.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Hashimoto disease may present with:
questions.explanation: Hashimoto's thyroiditis can present with a goiter, myxedema (hypothyroidism), or transient thyrotoxicosis (Hashitoxicosis).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Hoarseness of voice denotes:
options: Compression of the superior laryngeal nerve
Infiltration of the recurrent laryngeal nerve
Infiltration of the superior laryngeal nerve
questions.explanation: Infiltration or damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve paralyzes the vocal cord, causing hoarseness.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Hypertension in a patient with a family history of medullary thyroid carcinoma is most often due to:
questions.explanation: Medullary thyroid carcinoma is associated with MEN 2A and 2B syndromes, which also include pheochromocytoma, leading to hypertension.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Hypothyroidism is most often due to:
questions.explanation: In developed areas, iatrogenic causes (post-surgery, post-radioiodine) and autoimmune destruction (Hashimoto's) are leading causes of hypothyroidism.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In Hashimoto's disease (Lymphadenoid goiter), which statement is false?
options: It is characterized by uniform smooth enlargement of the gland with hard consistency
It may be associated with hypothyroidism
It has a characteristic histological picture
It is best treated by radiotherapy
questions.explanation: Hashimoto's is treated with hormone replacement or surgery; radiotherapy is not a standard treatment.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In physiological goiter, which statement is false?
options: It affects males more often than females
It presents as fullness of the neck
It is characterized by uniform smooth enlargement with fleshy or firm consistency
It may be associated with toxic or pressure symptoms
questions.explanation: Physiological goiter (e.g., puberty goiter) is a simple, non-toxic enlargement and does not typically present with toxic symptoms or significant pressure symptoms.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In subacute thyroiditis (de Quervain's disease), it is untrue that it:
options: Has a sudden onset with fever and painful swelling
May cause radiating pain in the ear
questions.explanation: Subacute thyroiditis is a self-limiting condition that typically resolves spontaneously over months.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In thyroid carcinoma, mediastinal node involvement is a feature of which type?
questions.explanation: Medullary carcinoma is known for aggressive lymphatic spread, often involving mediastinal nodes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Medical treatment of thyrotoxicosis is least useful in:
questions.explanation: Secondary thyrotoxicosis (toxic nodular goiter/adenoma) usually needs definitive treatment—surgery or radioiodine—since antithyroid drugs rarely induce long-term remission.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most diagnostic single investigation for toxic adenoma is:
questions.explanation: A thyroid radioisotope scan is the key test, showing a 'hot' nodule with suppressed surrounding tissue, confirming toxic adenoma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: On the 5th postoperative day after total thyroidectomy, a patient complains of tingling of the fingertips and has a serum calcium level of 5.5 mg/dL. The next step should be:
options: Administration of vitamin D2 or D3 50,000-100,000 units/day
Administration of calcium gluconate 3-6 g/day, by slow IV drip
questions.explanation: A serum calcium level of 5.5 mg/dL indicates severe hypocalcemia. Immediate correction with IV calcium gluconate is required to prevent tetany and cardiac complications.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Preparation of a patient with retrosternal goiter for surgery includes:
questions.explanation: Beta-blockers like propranolol are used to manage potential hemodynamic stress or cardiovascular symptoms, especially if the patient has toxic components or requires cardiac stabilization.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Presentations of ectopic thyroid include:
questions.explanation: Ectopic thyroids can cause swelling, speech difficulties (dysarthria), and if it's the only thyroid tissue, its removal can lead to hypothyroidism (myxedema).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Recurrent goiter may be due to:
questions.explanation: Recurrence can occur due to insufficient tissue removal, persistent underlying cause (e.g., TSH stimulation), or complications like granuloma formation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Sporadic goiter may occur due to the following except:
questions.explanation: Iodine deficiency causes 'Endemic' goiter. 'Sporadic' goiter affects individuals and is caused by goitrogens, congenital defects, or pollutants.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The best routine treatment for multinodular goiter is:
questions.explanation: For multinodular goiter, subtotal thyroidectomy is traditionally performed to remove the bulk of the diseased tissue while preserving some function. Total thyroidectomy is increasingly favored.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The correct sequence of events for the metabolism of iodine and synthesis of thyroid hormone is:
questions.explanation: The process involves iodine trapping by the thyroid, oxidation, organification (binding to thyroglobulin), coupling of iodotyrosines, and finally release of thyroid hormones.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The daily requirement of iodine is:
questions.explanation: The typical adult daily iodine requirement is approximately 100-150 micrograms (mcg).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements about thyroglossal cysts are true except:
options: They usually present as midline neck swelling
They may be confused with ectopic thyroid
They should be excised completely due to potential complications
questions.explanation: Thyroglossal cysts require surgical excision due to the risk of infection and potential malignancy; observation is not recommended.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements about treatment of thyrotoxicosis by radioactive iodine are true except that it:
options: Is contraindicated in patients below the age of 40
Is particularly useful in elderly and thyrocardiac patients
Produces its beneficial effects within a few days
Carries the risk of late occurrence of thyroid cancer
questions.explanation: Radioactive iodine (RAI) takes weeks to months to show full clinical benefit, not a few days.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements regarding TSH measurement are true except:
options: It is increased after total thyroidectomy
It is the most sensitive test for mild cases
questions.explanation: While TSH levels vary, a normal range is typically lower than 5 microunits/liter (often around 0.4-4.0). A level of 5 might be considered high.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following type of thyroiditis mimics malignancy:
questions.explanation: Riedel's thyroiditis, characterized by dense fibrosis, can present as a hard, fixed mass that closely mimics hard, invasive carcinoma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common cause of goitrous hypothyroidism in adults is:
questions.explanation: Hashimoto's disease is the leading cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas and typically presents with a firm, enlarged thyroid (goiter).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common site of a thyroglossal cyst is:
questions.explanation: The subhyoid position is the most frequent location for thyroglossal cysts along their developmental tract.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most frequent cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is:
questions.explanation: A single parathyroid adenoma accounts for approximately 85% of primary hyperparathyroidism cases.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most frequent variety of thyroid cancer is:
questions.explanation: Papillary carcinoma constitutes about 80-85% of all thyroid cancers.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The term 'lateral aberrant thyroid' really implies:
options: Congenital aberrant thyroid tissue lateral to the thyroid
A metastasis in a cervical lymph node from an occult thyroid carcinoma
A metastasis from carcinoma of the larynx
An implanted thyroid piece in a thyroidectomy scar
questions.explanation: Historically mistaken for ectopic tissue, 'lateral aberrant thyroid' is now understood to be a lymph node metastasis from a differentiated thyroid carcinoma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Thyroid carcinoma during pregnancy, the appropriate treatment is:
questions.explanation: Surgery (thyroidectomy) can be safely performed during pregnancy. Radioactive iodine is contraindicated due to fetal thyroid damage.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Thyroid disease treatment:
options: Follicular carcinoma -> total thyroidectomy and radioiodine
// // → completion thyroidectomy + radioiodine; autonomous nodule >45 years → radioiodine.
questions.explanation: All listed treatments are standard for their respective conditions.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Thyrotoxicosis during pregnancy is best treated by:
questions.explanation: Medical management with antithyroid drugs like carbimazole is the treatment of choice. PTU is preferred in the first trimester.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Thyrotoxicosis in children, all statements are correct except:
options: Medical treatment alone can control the disease
Radioactive iodine is the ideal treatment
Thyroidectomy should be near total to avoid recurrence
questions.explanation: Radioactive iodine is generally avoided in children due to potential long-term risks. Medical treatment or surgery is preferred.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Toxic goiter has the following signs except:
questions.explanation: Toxic goiter causes fine, rapid tremors. Flapping tremors (asterixis) are associated with liver or renal failure.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: True statements about papillary carcinoma of the thyroid do not include that it:
questions.explanation: Papillary carcinoma primarily spreads via lymphatics. Hematogenous spread is rare and more characteristic of follicular carcinoma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Voice fatigue after thyroidectomy is due to injury to which nerve?
questions.explanation: Injury to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve affects the cricothyroid muscle, leading to voice fatigue and loss of high pitch.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 'warm' nodule means:
questions.explanation: A 'warm' nodule takes up isotope similarly to normal thyroid tissue, indicating activity. A 'hot' nodule is hyperactive (toxic).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding follicular adenoma is true:
options: It presents clinically as a solitary nodule
Distinction between follicular adenoma and carcinoma can only be made by histological examination
In adenoma, there is no invasion of the capsule or pericapsular blood vessels
questions.explanation: Follicular adenomas cannot be definitively distinguished from carcinoma by FNA; histological examination showing lack of capsular/vascular invasion is diagnostic. Lobectomy is the preferred treatment.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following treatment schedules for diffuse toxic goiter is true?
options: Under 45 years with large goiter: surgery
Under 45 years with small goiter: antithyroid drugs
questions.explanation: Standard treatment: antithyroid drugs for young/mild cases, surgery for large goiters or refusal of other options, radioiodine for older patients or high surgical risk.
questions.subject: General Surgery
